document.masterDocTitle: Contrasting species diversification of Eutarsopolipus (Acariformes: Podapolipidae) on Castelnaudia and Notonomus (Coleoptera: Carabidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Contrasting species diversification of Eutarsopolipus (Acariformes: Podapolipidae) on Castelnaudia and Notonomus (Coleoptera: Carabidae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Adult female: setae sc1 , c1, c2, d, f with thickened bases, finely tapering (rarely asymmetrically not tapering); anterior margin of prodorsal shield eroded, concave; setae v1 9â€“11. Larviform male: sc1 9. Larval female: Setae c1 16â€“17, d 11â€“12, f 10â€“11.

( QMS 113562 )
. Paratypes . All ex.
C. setosiceps .

;

Note: one female specimen from the Crater was too poor to include in the type series (QMS 113575). One pharate female from the Crater (QMS 113576).

Gnathosoma .
Length 60 (58â€“64), width 55 (52â€“62). Cheliceral stylets 73 (68â€“75), setae ch 21 (19â€“24), su 14 (11â€“13).

Idiosoma
( Figs 1â€“2 , 10 ). Length 340 (340â€“400), width 265 (255â€“350). Prodorsal plate eroded mid-anteriorly and anterolaterally; setae v1 11 (9â€“11), v2 alveolar remnant, sc1 20 (15â€“19), sc2 66 (65â€“74); setae sc1 thickened but not bulbous ( Fig. 10 ). Distance between setae v1â€“v1 46 (46â€“53), sc1â€“sc1 92 (100â€“105), v1â€“sc1 31 (28â€“35), v2â€“v2 44 (50â€“52), sc2â€“sc2 135 (135â€“140), sc1â€“sc2 35 (31â€“35). Opisthosomal setae c1, c2, d, f thickened, sometimes appearing stout by lacking fine tips, especially setae c2 ( Figs 1 , 10 ). Plate C setae c1 17 (11â€“21), c2 8 (8â€“18), distance between setae c1â€“c1 96 (92â€“100). Plate D setae d 14 (13â€“20), dâ€“d 145 (145â€“165), cupuli ia laterad d . Plate EF setae f 14 (14â€“18), fâ€“f 130 (115â€“155), cupuli im laterad f . Plate H almost completely divided into two small plates, often ventral, seta h 7 (5â€“6). Venter ( Fig. 2 ): coxisterna 1 and 2 well defined, coxisterna 3 weakly defined; coxal setae slender, 1a 5 (4â€“5), 2a 8 (7â€“8), 3a 6 (7â€“8), 3b 8 (9â€“11). Alveoli of 1b, 2b present.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnathosoma
. Length 33, width 30. Cheliceral stylets 25, setae ch 5, su 6.

Idiosoma
( Figs 4â€“5 ). Length 165, width 130. Prodorsal plate with setae v1 5, v2 alveolar remnant, sc1 9, sc2 85. Distance between setae v1â€“v1 22, sc1â€“sc1 48, v1â€“sc1 18, v2â€“v2 28, sc2â€“sc2 60, sc1â€“sc2 21. Plate CD setae c1 6, c2 5, d 6, distance between setae c1â€“c1 40, c1â€“c2 30, dâ€“d 41; cupuli ia laterad setae d (asymmetrical expression). Plate EF concave, eroded posteriorly; with setae f 3, distance fâ€“f 28; cupuli im anterolaterad setae f . Genital capsule length 29, width 34, setae h minute. Venter ( Fig. 4 ): coxal setae 1a 3, 2a 4, 3a 5, 3b 5.

Legs . Setal counts legs Iâ€“III, femur-tarsus: 3-2-6(+ Ï† )-8(+ Ï‰ ), 0-1-4-6, 0-1-4-6. Leg I. subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnathosoma
. Length 50â€“51, width 46â€“50. Palp with minute dorsal femoral seta. Cheliceral stylets 62â€“65, setae ch 20â€“27, su 10â€“11.

Idiosoma
( Fig. 6 ). Length 225â€“240, width 175â€“185. Prodorsal plate overlapping folded membranous cuticle (outline shown in figure), with setae v1 5â€“6, v2 alveolar remnant, sc1 9â€“10, sc2 100â€“120. Distance between setae v1â€“v1 33â€“37, sc1â€“sc1 68â€“70, v1â€“sc1 26â€“28, v2â€“v2 36â€“39, sc2â€“sc2 85â€“88, sc1â€“sc2 34â€“37. Plate C setae c1 16â€“17, c2 10â€“11, distance between setae c1â€“c1 49â€“52. Plate D setae d 11â€“12, dâ€“d 61â€“62, cupuli ia very close to setae d, anteriad to anterolaterad d . Plate EF setae f 10â€“11, fâ€“f 52â€“57, cupuli im close to setae f, anterolaterad f . Plate H narrow, 16â€“19 wide, ca. 25â€“30 long bearing setae h1 ca. 180, h2 11â€“12. Venter ( Fig. 7 ): coxisterna 1-2 well defined, coxisterna 3 poorly defined, membranous; coxal setae slender, 1a 2â€“3, 2a 4â€“5, 3a 6â€“7, 3b 5. Alveoli of 1b , 2b present.

Legs ( Fig. 8 ). Setal counts legs Iâ€“III, femur-tarsus: 3-2-6(+ Ï† )-8(+ Ï‰ ), 0-1-4-6, 0-1-4-6. Leg I. Femur I, d minute, lâ€² minute, vâ€³ 6â€“9; genu I, lâ€² 2, lâ€³ 2; tibia I, d 53â€“60, lâ€™ 8â€“9, lâ€™â€™ 11â€“13, vâ€™ 2â€“3, vâ€™â€™ 12â€“13, k 6â€“7, Ï† 10â€“11; tarsus I, tcâ€™ 15â€“16, tcâ€™â€™ 16â€“18, plâ€™ 9â€“10, plâ€™â€™ 17â€“20, pvâ€² 2, pvâ€™â€™ 3, Ï‰ 3, s 5, uâ€²â€² minute. Leg II. Genu II, lâ€² 2â€“3; tibia II, d 35â€“40, lâ€™ 6â€“7, vâ€™ 13â€“15, vâ€™â€™ 14â€“20; tarsus II, tcâ€² 2â€“3, tc â€³ 4â€“5, pl â€³ 40â€“43, pvâ€™â€™ 3, uâ€™ 6, uâ€²â€² 2. Leg III. Genu III, lâ€² 2â€“3; tibia III, d 29â€“45, lâ€™ 6â€“8, vâ€™ 12â€“17, vâ€™â€™ 15â€“17; tarsus III, tcâ€™ 2â€“3, tc â€³ 4â€“5, pl â€³ 30â€“35, pvâ€™â€™ 3, uâ€™ 6â€“7, uâ€²â€² minute.

Differential diagnosis. Female
E. hadros
sp. nov.
has idiosomal setae that are less thickened than those of
E. mixtus
sp. nov.
and
E. umbonatus
sp. nov.
, giving these setae a comparatively slender appearance. See Fig. 10 and the Differential diagnosis for
E. mixtus
for further discussion of this feature. The anterior margin of the prodorsal shield of female
E. hadros
is also deeply eroded medially; this erosion is weak in
E. umbonatus
and absent in
E. mixtus .
The male of
E. hadros
has a longer seta sc1 (9 versus 3â€“6 in
E. mixtus
and
E. umbonatus
), but the single male specimen of
E. hadros
reduces confidence in this possible diagnostic feature. Larval female
E. hadros
are difficult to distinguish from
E. mixtus
, but the size of setae f (10â€“11 versus 14â€“19) is useful. Larvae of
E. hadros
are distinguished from
E. umbonatus
by having longer setae c1 (16â€“19 versus 8â€“11).

Etymology. The specific name
hadros
(Greek, strong, stout) alludes to the strong dorsal setae.
